isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEHR POWER SYSTEMS/POWERLINE ALTERNATORS USED ON EMERGENCY VEHICLES - RATING CHARGING SYSTEMS / ALTERNATORS

svcproc.title: SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS
svcproc.para: Emergency vehicles operate in situations which may overload charging systems and cause decreased system voltage. An overloaded charging system may cause the engine to shut down, damage the alternator or reduce battery life.

Accessories, such as lights, radios and sirens, put additional loads on the charging system. When the incorrect size alternator is used or the system is not optimized with fast idle devices, optimum pulley ratios, and sufficient sized battery cables, system overload is likely to occur.
Engines on emergency vehicles are prone to sit at idle for extended periods of time. An alternator will not put out it's rated amperage during engine idle.
To determine if the alternator installed on the vehicle will provide sufficient current, several factors need to be considered:

step1.para: Understand all of the electrical loads of the vehicle.
Understand the operating conditions of the vehicle. Will the vehicle sit running at idle with full electrical loads for long periods of time?

What is the pulley ratio of the alternator? Measure both the engine pulley outside diameter (O.D.) and the alternator pulley O.D. Divide the engine pulley measurement by the alternator pulley measurement. Example: engine pulley O.D. = 6.5 inches alternator pulley O.D. = 3.0 inches pulley ratio = 6.5/3.0 =2.17 This means that for every revolution of the engine the alternator makes 2.17 revolutions. If the engine is idling at 700 RPM, the alternator is turning at 2.17 X 700 RPM = 1519 RPM.

How much current will the alternator provide at idle? Using the power curves in this manual, determine the output of the alternator at the operating temperature of the vehicle. Example: With the engine compartment temperature at 200°F (93°C) and the alternator turning at 1519 RPM, the power curve for the 25-35 200 amp alternator shows 30 amps available to the system.

svcproc.para: Any current required by the system, not supplied by the alternator, will be drawn from the battery. As the battery voltage decreases the alternator will work harder to compensate. This may damage the alternator.

During a return trip from an emergency, engines may not be run at high speeds long enough to recharge the vehicle batteries. No alternator is large enough to return hundreds of amp hours to a battery in a few minutes. A truck that encounters an overload condition will probably not survive a run that starts with a weak or partially discharged battery.

To prevent overloading the charging system, insure the alternator is rated higher than the maximum current that could be required by the vehicle, use fast idle devices and optimize the charging system. It may be necessary to use an external battery charger to charge the vehicle batteries when the vehicle is parked.
